- ry logs -- show recent logs across all engines
- ry logs --engine <id> -- filter to a specific engine
- ry logs --bead <id> -- filter to a specific bead

title: Fix dispatch to be interactive instead of fire-and-forget
description:
Dispatch currently launches Claude with `-p` flag which makes it a one-shot prompt that processes once and exits. The system prompt says 'Monitor for incoming feature requests' but Claude cannot actually monitor anything — it runs once and the tmux pane goes idle.

The intended purpose (per ARCHITECTURE.md) is that Dispatch is 'the user's primary interface' for decomposing feature requests into beads. This requires an interactive session, not a fire-and-forget.

**Current behavior:** `ry dispatch` runs `claude --dangerously-skip-permissions --system-prompt <prompt> -p <one-shot>` → Claude responds once → process exits → tmux pane idle.

**Desired behavior:** Dispatch should be an interactive Claude session the user can attach to and converse with. Options:
1. Drop the `-p` flag and launch `claude` interactively (user attaches to tmux pane)
2. Use a CLAUDE.md with the dispatch prompt instead of `--system-prompt` so the session has persistent context
3. Potentially use `--stdin` for programmatic interaction

**Files:** `internal/dispatch/dispatch.go`, `internal/dispatch/prompt.go`, `cmd/ry/dispatch.go`
close_reason: Removed -p flag making dispatch interactive. Switched to --append-system-prompt and connected stdin.

title: Exclude railyard.yaml and orchestration files from engine agent visibility
description:
## Problem

When an engine's Claude Code session searches/reads the project repo, it sees `railyard.yaml` which contains Dolt database connection config (host, port, database name). This confused the agent during a todo app test — it saw the database name and incorporated it into its work instead of building the requested in-memory store.

Engines work in git worktrees (`engines/<engineID>/`) which are checkouts of the same repo, so all repo files including `railyard.yaml` are visible to the Claude Code subprocess.

Other Railyard artifacts that could cause similar confusion:
- `railyard.yaml` — Dolt DB config, track definitions, stall thresholds
- `engines/` directory — other engine worktrees (shouldn't be visible, already gitignored?)
- `.beads/` directory — issue tracking data

## Approach Options

### Option A: .claudeignore in worktree (preferred)
Claude Code respects `.claudeignore` files (same format as `.gitignore`). Before spawning the agent, the engine could write a `.claudeignore` into the worktree that excludes Railyard files:
```
railyard.yaml
.beads/
engines/
```
This is the cleanest solution — the agent never sees the files at all.

Implementation: In `EnsureWorktree()` or `SpawnAgent()` in `internal/engine/git.go` or `internal/engine/subprocess.go`, write the `.claudeignore` file before launching claude.

### Option B: System prompt instruction
Add a line to `writeInstructions()` in `internal/engine/context.go` telling the agent to ignore `railyard.yaml`. Less robust — agents can still stumble on it during file searches.

### Option C: Both
Write `.claudeignore` AND mention it in the prompt for belt-and-suspenders safety.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Engine agents cannot see or search `railyard.yaml` during their work
- [ ] `.claudeignore` is written to the worktree before the Claude Code subprocess starts
- [ ] Excluded files: `railyard.yaml`, `.beads/`, `engines/`
- [ ] The `.claudeignore` is not committed to git (it lives only in the worktree)
- [ ] Existing tests still pass
- [ ] Verify by checking that `buildCommand()` in subprocess.go runs after the ignore file is in place
close_reason: Implemented .claudeignore in worktrees, fixed stall re-claim loop, added engine restart to yardmaster/dispatch prompts

title: Add engine-to-yardmaster bug escalation flow
description:
When an engine files a bug car (per railyard-s6v), the yardmaster needs to know about it and triage it. Currently the yardmaster prompt (internal/yardmaster/prompt.go) has no awareness of engine-filed bugs.

This issue adds the yardmaster-side handling:

1. **Bug triage in monitoring loop**: Yardmaster should check for newly created bug cars (status=open, type=bug) during its monitoring cycle and decide: assign to an engine immediately, add dependencies to block other work, or escalate to human.

2. **Priority assessment**: Yardmaster should have rules for bug priority — a security issue or broken test should be P0/P1 and may need to pause other work. A minor inconsistency can be P3.

3. **Cross-car impact**: If a bug affects a car that's currently in_progress, yardmaster should message that engine to warn them.

Acceptance criteria:
- [ ] Add 'Bug Triage' section to yardmaster prompt in prompt.go
- [ ] Include rules: check for new bug cars, assess priority, decide on assignment vs. escalation
- [ ] Add instruction to message engines if a bug affects their in-progress car
- [ ] Add ry car list --type bug to the monitoring loop commands
- [ ] Existing tests still pass

title: Stalled engine recovery: teach agents ry engine restart and fix stale car claims
description:
## Problem

Multiple issues around stalled engine recovery:

1. **Dispatch used `ry start` to restart a stalled engine** — this starts the full orchestration (Dispatch + Yardmaster + engines) instead of restarting just one engine. Dispatch doesn't know about `ry engine restart <engine-id>`.

2. **Yardmaster prompt doesn't include `ry engine restart`** — the yardmaster prompt (`internal/yardmaster/prompt.go`) has a 'Stalled Engine' decision rule that marks engines dead and releases cars, but never restarts them. The command exists (`orchestration.RestartEngine()`) but yardmaster doesn't know about it.

3. **Stale car claims create re-claim loops** — when HandleStall marks a car as 'blocked' and the engine is still alive, the engine daemon's `claimOrReclaim()` (`cmd/ry/engine.go:339`) re-claims it because 'blocked' != 'done'/'cancelled'. The engine loops trying to work on a blocked car forever.

4. **Done cars stuck as claimed** — if a car reaches status 'done' but the engine's `current_car` field wasn't cleared (e.g., process died between completion and cleanup), yardmaster should detect and clean this up so the engine can move on.

5. **Dispatch shouldn't manage engines directly** — engine lifecycle is yardmaster's job. Dispatch should know to describe the problem and let yardmaster handle it, or at most use `ry engine restart`.

## Changes Required

### 1. Yardmaster prompt (`internal/yardmaster/prompt.go`)
- Add `ry engine restart <engine-id>` to Available Commands section
- Update 'Stalled Engine' decision rule: after releasing the car, restart the engine (not just mark dead)
- Add new decision rule 'Stale Car Claim': if car status=done but engine still has it as current_car, clear the claim (`ry car update <id> --assignee ""`)
- Add `ry engine list` and `ry engine restart` to the monitoring loop

### 2. Engine daemon stall recovery (`cmd/ry/engine.go`)
- In the `outcomeStall` case (line 280), after HandleStall, also clear `eng.CurrentCar` and update the DB so the engine doesn't re-claim the blocked car
- In `claimOrReclaim()`, add 'blocked' to the statuses that trigger clearing current_car (alongside 'done' and 'cancelled')

### 3. Dispatch prompt (`internal/dispatch/prompt.go`)
- Add a brief note that engine management (restarts, stall recovery) is yardmaster's responsibility
- If Dispatch needs an engine restarted, it should message yardmaster rather than using `ry start`

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] Yardmaster prompt includes `ry engine restart <engine-id>` in available commands
- [ ] Yardmaster 'Stalled Engine' rule uses restart instead of just marking dead
- [ ] Yardmaster has 'Stale Car Claim' detection rule
- [ ] Engine daemon clears current_car after stall outcome (no re-claim loop)
- [ ] `claimOrReclaim()` treats 'blocked' as a terminal status (clears current_car)
- [ ] Dispatch prompt notes that engine lifecycle = yardmaster responsibility
- [ ] Existing tests still pass
close_reason: Implemented .claudeignore in worktrees, fixed stall re-claim loop, added engine restart to yardmaster/dispatch prompts

title: Exclude epic cars from engine claiming — epics are not implementable work
description:
## Problem

The engine `ClaimCar()` query (`internal/engine/claim.go:36`) and `ReadyCars()` (`internal/car/deps.go:73`) have **no type filter**. They find any car with `status=open` and no unresolved blockers, regardless of type.

This caused a real issue: a frontend track engine picked up an epic car (the only one in ready status). The epic's subtasks were all blocked on backend track work. The engine spawned a Claude Code session that had nothing actionable to do, leading to a stall.

**Epics are container cars** — they group related work but are not directly implementable. An engine should never claim an epic. Epics should auto-close when all their children are done.

### Root Cause
`ClaimCar()` query:
```go
result := tx.Where("status = ? AND (assignee = ? OR assignee IS NULL) AND track = ?", "open", "", track).
    Where("id NOT IN (?)", blockedSub).
    Order("priority ASC, created_at ASC").
    Limit(1).
    Find(&claimed)
```
No `.Where("type != ?", "epic")` clause.

Same for `ReadyCars()`:
```go
q := db.Where("status = ? AND (assignee = ? OR assignee IS NULL)", "open", "").
    Where("id NOT IN (?)", blockedSub)
```

### Related Issue
When an engine claims a car whose children are all blocked on another track, it stalls with nothing to do. Beyond filtering epics, consider: should the engine be able to unclaim a car and move on if it detects the work is blocked? (This relates to railyard-f3r stalled engine recovery.)

## Changes Required

### 1. Filter epics from ClaimCar (`internal/engine/claim.go`)
Add `.Where("type != ?", "epic")` to the claim query so engines never claim epics.

### 2. Filter epics from ReadyCars (`internal/car/deps.go`)
Add the same filter to `ReadyCars()` so `ry car ready` doesn't show epics as claimable.

### 3. Auto-close epics when children complete (`internal/yardmaster/switch.go`)
After `UnblockDeps()` in the Switch flow, check if the merged car's parent is an epic and all siblings are done. If so, auto-close the epic.

### 4. Consider spike type
Spikes (research tasks) ARE implementable — engines should be able to claim them. Only exclude `type=epic`.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] `ClaimCar()` never returns a car with type=epic
- [ ] `ReadyCars()` never returns a car with type=epic  
- [ ] Add test in `claim_test.go`: epic car with status=open and no deps is NOT claimed
- [ ] Add test in `deps_test.go`: epic doesn't appear in ReadyCars results
- [ ] Epic auto-close: when all children of an epic are done, epic status transitions to done
- [ ] Existing tests still pass
close_reason: Filtered epics from ClaimCar and ReadyCars queries, added TryCloseEpic auto-close after merge, added tests

title: Enhance Dispatch prompt with full workflow awareness and conventions guidance
description:
The Dispatch system prompt (internal/dispatch/prompt.go) covers car creation, dependencies, and decomposition rules, but has gaps:

1. **No awareness of test_command**: Dispatch doesn't know about the per-track test_command field, so it can't mention it in car descriptions or remind agents to run the right test runner.

2. **No conventions injection**: The prompt template renders track names, languages, file_patterns, and engine_slots — but NOT the conventions map. Dispatch should see what conventions are configured (e.g., 'framework: Laravel 11', 'style: PSR-12') so it can reference them in car descriptions it generates.

3. **No guidance on car description quality**: Dispatch creates cars but has no explicit rules about what makes a good description. It should be told to include: specific file paths, error handling expectations, test coverage requirements, and references to track conventions.

4. **No bug/spike workflow**: Dispatch only shows epic and task examples. It should know when to create spikes (research unknowns before committing to implementation) and how to create bug cars when the user reports issues.

5. **No awareness of engine capabilities**: Dispatch doesn't know that engines can split work, file bugs, or ask yardmaster for help. This context would help Dispatch create better-scoped cars (not too large, not too small).

Acceptance criteria:
- [ ] Add conventions rendering to the prompt template (iterate .Tracks[].Conventions and display them)
- [ ] Add test_command to the track info section
- [ ] Add a 'Writing Good Car Descriptions' section with rules: include file paths, specify test expectations, reference conventions, define edge cases and error handling
- [ ] Add spike and bug type examples to the decomposition rules
- [ ] Add a brief note about engine capabilities (can split work, file bugs, message yardmaster) so Dispatch sizes cars appropriately

title: Enhance engine instructions for bug detection and issue creation
description:
Currently engine context (internal/engine/context.go writeInstructions()) has three sections: 'When You're Done', 'If You're Stuck', and 'If You Need to Split Work'. The split work section only mentions creating child tasks. Engines should also know when and how to create bug issues for problems they discover that are outside the scope of their current car.

Examples of when an engine should file a bug:
- Discovers a failing test in code they didn't write
- Finds an API inconsistency between modules  
- Encounters a broken dependency or import
- Notices a security issue in existing code
- Finds that acceptance criteria for a completed car weren't actually met

The engine should NOT file bugs for problems within their own car's scope — those are just part of the work.

Acceptance criteria:
- [ ] Add a new '## If You Discover a Bug' section to writeInstructions() in context.go

title: Add real human notification mechanism for escalations
description:
## Problem

Currently yardmaster escalation to humans is just a DB message:
```
ry message send --from yardmaster --to human --subject "escalate" --body "..."
```

This message sits in the Dolt `messages` table until someone manually runs `ry inbox --agent human`. There is no push notification, no terminal alert, no external integration. In practice, the human never sees the escalation unless they're actively polling.

## What's Needed

A notification mechanism that actually reaches the human operator. Options (not mutually exclusive):

### Option A: Terminal notification (minimum viable)
- When yardmaster sends a message to 'human', write to a visible location: tmux status bar, a dedicated tmux pane, or a desktop notification via `notify-send` / `osascript`
- Simplest: yardmaster pane prints a prominent banner that the human sees when they check tmux
- Could also use `tmux display-message` to flash a notification across all panes

### Option B: Webhook integration
- Add optional `notifications` config section in `railyard.yaml`:
```yaml
notifications:
  webhook_url: https://hooks.slack.com/services/...
  # or
  command: "notify-send 'Railyard' '{{.Subject}}: {{.Body}}'"
```
- When a message targets 'human' or has priority 'urgent', fire the webhook/command
- Implementation: `internal/messaging/notify.go` with a `Notify()` function called after `Send()`

### Option C: `ry watch` command
- A blocking command that streams messages to human in real-time
- `ry watch --agent human` — polls inbox and prints new messages as they arrive
- Simpler than webhook, works in any terminal

## Suggested Approach
Start with Option A (tmux display-message) + Option C (`ry watch`). Webhook can come later.

## Files to Modify
- `internal/messaging/send.go` — add notification hook after Send()
- `internal/config/config.go` — add optional NotificationConfig
- `internal/orchestration/orchestration.go` — possibly add a notification pane
- `cmd/ry/` — add `ry watch` command

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] When yardmaster escalates to human, the human gets a visible notification
- [ ] At minimum: tmux display-message shows the escalation text across the session
- [ ] `ry watch --agent human` command streams incoming messages in real-time
- [ ] Existing tests still pass
- [ ] Optional: webhook/command config in railyard.yaml for external notifications
close_reason: Implemented ry watch command + notification hook in messaging.Send()
